Issues.Title: Installation tutorial on older documents is installing the latest version of @angular/cli
Issues.Body: # üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description I was taking a look at the old documentation and I noticed that the installation command was the same used to install the latest version of @angular/cli npm i @angular/cli@ -g I supposed that the correct command would be something like: npm i @angular/cli@^8 -g ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://v8.angular.io/guide/setup-local ### Reproduction Steps** - Open https://v8.angular.io/guide/setup-local - See the "Install the Angular CLI" step - Execute "npm i -g @angular/cli" on terminal - "Run the command "ng version" ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** Expected: Package Version ------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.803.29 @angular-devkit/core 8.3.29 @angular-devkit/schematics 8.3.29 @schematics/angular 8.3.29 @schematics/update 0.803.29 rxjs 6.4.0 Actual behavior: @angular-devkit/architect 0.1100.2 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/core 11.0.2 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/schematics 11.0.2 (cli-only) @schematics/angular 11.0.2 (cli-only) @schematics/update 0.1100.2 (cli-only) [](url) ## üì∑Screenshot ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17017573/100032965-f06fa800-2dd7-11eb-855d-3f5b051215f1.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Installation tutorial on older documents is installing the latest version of @angular/cli" (#39821)

Issues.Title: ByPass Security Trust HTML and ByPass Security Trust Style
Issues.Body:
I will explain with the issue with the written text 

In my case, From API Response, it is receiving the Styles and HTML. So i have to bind in UI with including the styles. 
I have followed two approaches for this.. 
1) When using the byPassSecurityTrustHTML => all the styles and Html is binded to UI, but the entire application styles are overriden with this styles when i am on this page. 
2) When using the sanitize(SecurityContext.HTML, 'HTML') => the styles are not applied to this 

So, could you please mention, that.. how to use the styles and HTML to the same element, from the api response.. without overriding the application styles.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ByPass Security Trust HTML and ByPass Security Trust Style" (#39820)

Issues.Title: Library is skipped by Ivy / ngcc compiler
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I'm not sure. Upgraded to angular 11 almost together with getting the issue - might be. ### Description I maintain a set of libraries to work with gRPC from Angular, here is the link: https://github.com/ngx-grpc/ngx-grpc The lib includes 6 libs (located in `packages`): - one non-angular (however located between angular apps, just is not present in angular.json) - protoc plugin - `protoc-gen-ng` - 4 normal angular libs - 1 angular lib; built using Angular toolset but is used inside a web worker - `worker`. There is also `examples` directory served as example and, well, as a test reference that all goes fine. This example uses all the libs, and this is the place where the error is happening. Now I added a module with forRoot / forChild in some of the angular libraries: core (2 modules), grpc-web-client (1 module) and worker-client (1 module). All modules and libs are working fine, all, but the latter one. It is just not processed by `ngcc`. When I start the application I see the following: ``` Compiling @ngx-grpc/common : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling @ngx-grpc/core : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling @ngx-grpc/- removing all references to the `Worker` type () : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling @ngx-grpc/well-known-types : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling @ngx-grpc/worker : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling @ngx-grpc/worker-client : es2015 as esm2015 ``` So, the ngcc reaches the library, but the directory `__ivy_ngcc__` is not created in `dist/worker-client`, however for all other modules it is created. The outcome is that the latter library does not work. What I tried: - removing all references to the `Worker` type from `worker-client` - did not help - checking angular config, including angular.json, tsconfigs and ng-packagr - did not help, it is totally equal to the working lib `grpc-web-client` - regenerated the lib from scratch - did not help - removed references to `worker` library from `worker-client` - did not help - moved code from `worker-client` to `grpc-web-client` lib. This **made the code work**, meaning that the `grpc-web-client` had no problems with ngcc; and I can use the code in the example and it works just fine. However, I cannot get more out of it; I still need the code in a separate package. This also means that code is valid and it can be compiled by ngcc, but for some reason when it's in its own package it does not. What is also very weird - I would not be surprised if I had problems with `worker` library; it's built by Angular and used in Worker. And I have a feeling it can be connected to the issue. I don't know what / where else to dig. The issue is driving me crazy. It seems unlogical to me and I cannot find the reason. Please help me out. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - Clone https://github.com/ngx-grpc/ngx-grpc - Switch to develop branch - `npm ci` - `npm run build` - builds the libs - `npm run examples` - produces the error after ngcc compiler ## üî• Exception or Error 

    Error: dist/worker-client/lib/grpc-worker-client.module.d.ts:11:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of GrpcWorkerClientExampleModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.
    
    This likely means that the dependency (@ngx-grpc/worker-client) which declares GrpcWorkerClientModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc.
    
    11 export declare class GrpcWorkerClientModule {
## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 11.0.2
Node: 14.5.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.0.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Nice jobs guys I really appreciate the work you are doing ...

I've been using ngx-i18n for dynamic translations in my former app; as I moved to Angular v11 I started using $localize instead of that library. at first, I should say it's great work but there's has some limitations around ...

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request
I want to be able to use parameters as $localize input to get translated!

For example:

```
const list = ['translate this A' translate this B,translate this C];
getTranslated() {
     return list.map(item => $localize(item));
}
```

### Relevant Package
@angular/localize

we cannot use $localize as a function that could accept a variable to translate.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
no idea yet.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
maybe making a pipe which has if statements inside.

Issues.Title: build(docs-infra): update docs examples to Angular v11.0.1
Issues.Body:
This PR updates the docs examples to Angular v11.0.1. In addition to updating the dependencies versions, it also updates the project's structure and config to more closely match what a new v11 CLI app would look like. See, also, the [diff][1] between a basic v10.1.3 CLI app and a v11.0.2 one.

It also disables the Selenium Promise Manager (as seen [here][2]) and switches all e2e tests to `async/await` (to align with new CLI v11 apps).

<sub>(Supercedes #39787.)</sub>

[1]: https://github.com/cexbrayat/angular-cli-diff/compare/10.1.3..11.0.2
[2]: https://github.com/cexbrayat/angular-cli-diff/compare/10.1.3...11.0.2diff-dbd675d74087d57cd084d6dd6ae24ae2eeff2ff0122680e12916052f8a843a29

Issues.Title: Difference between ng build and ng build --prod
Issues.Body:
Hello,

I haven't found [in the docs](https://angular.io/cli/build) any information about the default behavior when we do not specify the configuration by using `--configuration` or `--prod` parameter. Is the first configuration stated in `configurations` in the `angular.json` file used? Or is the default configuration the `production` one?

As i don't know which configuration is used when we don't specify any, I am not sure if there is any difference between running `ng build` and `ng build --prod` considering that we have only `production` configuration specified in our `angular.json` file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Difference between ng build and ng build --prod" (#39812)

Issues.Title: R3InjectorError with services not providedIn root
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? it worked for angular 9 and for 10. Somehow when I try to set the angular version to 10, I also run into this issue now. ### Description After updating to angular 11, my app started to show errors similar to this: ``` NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(AngularPageModule)[AngularService -> AngularService -> TestService -> TestService -> TestService] ``` Seems like the DependencyInjector has a problem to find services, which were not `providedIn: "root"`. So in the main scenario I consume `@ionic-native/file` or other native wrapper libraries. These come with services without the `providedIn: "root"` decorator. However the services consuming these libraries use the `providedIn: "root"` method. Only providing the service without the `providedIn` decorator, doesn't help. The only workaround I could find, is to manually provide the outer service and the ionic-native service.
In Code ionic.service.ts ```typescript import {Injectable} from '@angular/core'; import {File} from '@ionic-native/file/ngx'; @Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' }) export class IonicService { constructor(private readonly file: File) { } ... } ``` ionic.module.ts ```typescript import {NgModule} from '@angular/core'; import {CommonModule} from '@angular/common'; import {File} from '@ionic-native/file/ngx'; @NgModule({ declarations: [], imports: [ CommonModule ], providers: [ File ] }) export class IonicServiceModule { } ```
It also gets more confusing when using an angular library and try to use the `providedIn` method. When just using an angular app, you could provide the missing ionic-native service in the core `app.module.ts` and the DI is working. On the other hand, when you try the same thing with an angular lib (shown in the repo), it doesn't work. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/Fabiryn/angular-lib-injector-bug ## üî• Exception or Error 
ERROR Error: Uncaught (in promise): NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(AngularPageModule)[AngularService -> AngularService -> TestService -> TestService -> TestService]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for TestService!
NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(AngularPageModule)[AngularService -> AngularService -> TestService -> TestService -> TestService]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for TestService!
    at NullInjector.get (core.js:10756)
    at R3Injector.get (core.js:10923)
    at R3Injector.get (core.js:10923)
    at R3Injector.get (core.js:10923)
    at injectInjectorOnly (core.js:2290)
    at …µ…µinject (core.js:2294)
    at Object.AngularService_Factory [as factory] (herbert.js:93)
    at R3Injector.hydrate (core.js:11091)
    at R3Injector.get (core.js:10912)
    at NgModuleRef$1.get (core.js:24988)
    at resolvePromise (zone-evergreen.js:798)
    at resolvePromise (zone-evergreen.js:750)
    at zone-evergreen.js:860
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone-evergreen.js:399)
    at Object.onInvokeTask (core.js:28225)
    at ZoneDelegate.invokeTask (zone-evergreen.js:398)
    at Zone.runTask (zone-evergreen.js:167)
    at drainMicroTaskQueue (zone-evergreen.js:569)
    at ZoneTask.invokeTask [as invoke] (zone-evergreen.js:484)
    at invokeTask (zone-evergreen.js:1621)
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
Angular CLI: 11.0.2
Node: 14.15.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.0.2

Issues.Body:

peerDependencies to `^0.10.2 || ^ 0.11.3`, and the app will not show warning about
peer denepdency not consistent when using zone.js 0.10.x version.

Issues.Title: Angular 10 canLoad guard seems to not working properly
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/router ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 9.1.12 (v9-lts) ### Description After update Angular to v10 `canLoad` guard seems to not working as expected. In previous version works normally. On `canActivate` guard works as expected. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Code below with logs in JsDoc ``` @Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' }) export class GuardName implements CanActivate, CanLoad { constructor(private store: Store) {} canActivate(): Observable { return this.canEnter(); } canLoad(): Observable { return this.canEnter(); } private canEnter(): Observable { return this.checkStore().pipe( switchMap(() => of(true)), catchError(err => { console.log('err', err) throw err; }) ); } /** * Flow (can activate): * 1. loaded - boolean (not important) * 2. user log (null) * 3. user log (object) * 4. user loaded (object) * 5. withLatestFrom * * Flow (can load): * 1. loaded - boolean (not important) * 2. user log (null) * 3. user log (object) * 4. user loaded (object) * 5. withLatestFrom NOT REACHED, stuck on previous log * */ private checkStore(): Observable { return this.store.pipe( select(dictionaryLoaded), tap(r => console.log('loaded', r)), withLatestFrom(this.store.pipe( select(currentUser), tap(r => console.log('user log', r)), filter(user => !!user), tap(r => console.log('user loaded', r)), catchError(err => { console.log('err', err) throw err; }) )), tap(r => console.log('withLatestFrom', r)), catchError(err => { console.log('err', err) throw err; }), // rest of stuff, not important in that bug take(1) ); } } ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.2.0
Node: 12.18.1
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.2.3
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.1001.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.1002.0
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.1002.0
@angular-devkit/core               10.1.7
@angular-devkit/schematics         10.1.7
@angular/cdk                       10.2.7
@angular/cli                       10.2.0
@schematics/angular                10.1.7
@schematics/update                 0.1002.0

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): report error when a reference target is missing instead of crashing
Issues.Body:
If a template declares a reference to a missing target then referring to
that reference from elsewhere in the template would crash the template
type checker, due to a regression introduced in #38618. This commit
fixes the crash by ensuring that the invalid reference will resolve to
a variable of type any.

Fixes #39744
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler-cli): report error when a reference target is missing instead of crashing" (#39805)

Issues.Title: Polyfills / browser support confusion
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

A brand new Angular (10) installation comes with a `polyfills.ts` file saying: 
```
The current setup is for so-called "evergreen" browsers; the last versions of browsers that
automatically update themselves. This includes Safari >= 10, Chrome >= 55 (including Opera),
Edge >= 13 on the desktop, and iOS 10 and Chrome on mobile.

Learn more in https://angular.io/guide/browser-support
```
It has *no* polyfills as default.

The `https://angular.io/guide/browser-support` link says:

| Browsers (Desktop & Mobile)                           | Polyfills Required
| -----------------------------------------------------------   |:------------------------:|
| Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari, Android, IE 11  | ES2015

So, the pollyfills.ts comment says that Angular (seemingly) out of the box, with no polyfills supports Safari >= 10, Chrome >= 55 (including Opera), Edge >= 13 on the desktop, and iOS 10 and Chrome on mobile. While the documentation says you need the ES2015 polyfill to support Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Safari, Android, IE 11.

It also suggest polyfills: `ES7/array`, `ES2015` (which already is documented as *required* above) , `classList`, `Intl` and `Web Animations`.

Then, the `.browserslistrc` file says: 

```
not IE 11 # Angular supports IE 11 only as an opt-in. To opt-in, remove the 'not' prefix on this line.
```

I thought Browserslist only took care of css, but .browserslistrc says:

```
# This file is used by the build system to adjust CSS and JS output to support the specified browsers below.
```

...so apparently it also affect the JS output in some way.

Can someone shed a light on how this is all connected, and how Angular uses these tools behind the curtains? Both here, and in the documentation somewhere. If I missed it, please direct me. 

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**

https://angular.io/guide/browser-support#polyfill-libs

### Reproduction Steps**

`ng new myapp`

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**

?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Polyfills / browser support confusion" (#39793)

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
This feature request is for `@angular/core`

### Description

There should be a type alias defined for values that can be used as an "injection token". Today I think that is roughly `Type<T>|AbstractType<T>|InjectionToken<T>`. This type is repeated all over and defining a consistent alias would make it easier to update in the future and simplify code passing tokens around.

Forked from https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/37958


### Describe the solution you'd like

`type ????Token<T> = Type<T>|AbstractType<T>|InjectionToken<T>`

Not really sure on a name

Issues.Title: perf(compiler-cli): detect semantic changes and their effect on an in‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶cremental rebuild

In Angular programs, changing a file may require other files to be 
emitted as well due to implicit NgModule dependencies. For example, if
the selector of a directive is changed then all components that have 
that directive in their compilation scope need to be recompiled, as the
change of selector may affect the directive matching results.

Until now, the compiler solved this problem using a single dependency 
graph. The implicit NgModule dependencies were represented in this 
graph, such that a changed file would correctly also cause other files
to be re-emitted. This approach is limited in a few ways:

1. The file dependency graph is used to determine whether it is safe to
   reuse the analysis data of an Angular decorated class. This analysis
   data is invariant to unrelated changes to the NgModule scope, but
   because the single dependency graph also tracked the implicit 
   NgModule dependencies the compiler had to consider analysis data as 
   stale far more often than necessary.
2. It is typical for a change to e.g. a directive to not affect its 
   public API‚Äîits selector, inputs, outputs, or exportAs clause‚Äîin which
   case there is no need to re-emit all declarations in scope, as their
   compilation output wouldn't have changed.

This commit implements a mechanism by which the compiler is able to 
determine the impact of a change by comparing it to the prior 
compilation. To achieve this, a new graph is maintained that tracks all
public API information of all Angular decorated symbols. During an 
incremental compilation this information is compared to the information
that was captured in the most recently succeeded compilation. This 
determines the exact impact of the changes to the public API, which 
is then used to determine which files need to be re-emitted.

Note that the file dependency graph remains, as it is still used to 
track the dependencies of analysis data. This graph does no longer track
the implicit NgModule dependencies, which allows for better reuse of
analysis data.

This commit also fixes an incorrectness where a change to a declaration
in NgModule `A` would not cause the declarations in NgModules that
import from NgModule `A` to be re-emitted. This was intentionally 
incorrect as otherwise the performance of incremental rebuilds would 
have been far worse. This is no longer a concern, as the compiler is now
able to only re-emit when actually necessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(compiler-cli): detect semantic changes and their effect on an in‚Ä¶" (#39791)

Issues.Title: Angular v11 - Node v15 Compatibility - Karma test runner
Issues.Body: As per [Angular docs](https://angular.io/guide/setup-local), Angular supports current, active LTS, or maintenance LTS version of [Node.js](https://nodejs.org) And, according to [testing docs](https://angular.io/guide/testing), Karma is the default test runner. Does this mean tools provided by default in Angular CLI follow same node compatibility? Specifically, Should the default test framework, Karma, support node v15 (current)? Issues.Title: Webpack 5 & false circular dependency warning on .graphql custom compile step
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, my custom build step works flawlessly in Angular v10. ### Description I just switched to Webpack 5 (Angular 11) and I now get 1 warning per .graphql file: ``` Warning: Circular dependency detected: src/app/backbone/identity/person.graphql -> src/app/backbone/identity/person.graphql ``` Nothing fancy with my setup I think, just this webpack extra config: ```js module.exports = { module: { rules: [ { test: /\.(graphql|gql)$/, exclude: /node_modules/, loader: 'graphql-tag/loader', }, ], }, }; ``` My graphql files don't import themselves or other files. Just simple graphql queries & mutations. The warnings are there, but the app works well nonetheless. Issues.Title: Components using JSX does not trigger application rebuild when running ng serve and AOT
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.3.29 (maybe related to Ivy or AOT enabled while serving?) ### Description When an Angular component uses JSX syntax and thus is defined with `.tsx` extension instead of just `.ts` then compiler does not detect changes in Angular component related files `templateUrl` and `styleUrls`. Seems to work well when AOT is disabled. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Example application representing the issue: https://github.com/jsantha/angular-cli-tsx-component-not-rebuilding Reproduction: 1. Create a new Angular workspace and run `ng serve` 2. Create a new Angular component 3. Change component extension from `.ts` to `.tsx` (might need to enable jsx in tsconfig.json) 4. Make any change in component referenced files `templateUrl` or `styleUrls` 5. App does not pick up changes and not trigger rebuild ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Subresource Integrity for lazy modules is broken when using $localize
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When using `$localize` strings in a lazy module, the Subresource Integrity generation seems to produce invalid hashes for both the source language and any translated apps. This blocks the loading of lazy modules when `subresourceIntegrity` is enabled in the `angular.json` config. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I've created a minimal GitHub repository to reproduce the issue here: https://github.com/TimoWilhelm/lazy-demo Here are the steps to reproduce: - run `ng build --prod` - enter the dist folder of the app `cd ./dist/lazy-demo` - serve the app (I'm using [http-server](https://www.npmjs.com/package/http-server) to test) `http-server` - open the app in the browser at `http://127.0.0.1:8080` and open either `en-US` or `de`. - click the link to load the lazy module ## üî• Exception or Error 

Failed to find a valid digest in the 'integrity' attribute for resource 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/en-US/4.HASH.js' with computed SHA-256 integrity 'SHA'. The resource has been blocked.

Issues.Title: Library build using ng 11 breaks sourcemaps
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package I'm not 100% sure (don't know how to determine it), but I suspect one of: * @angular/compiler: 11 * ng-packagr: 11 * @angular-devkit/build-angular: ~0.1100.2 ### Is this a regression? Yes - library sourcemaps worked correctly in latest stable versions of ng 10. ### Description Library sourcemaps are no longer correct, and apps using these libraries can't be debugged using source file breakpoints. In ng 10, sourcemap files were correct; after upgrading to ng 11 dependencies, the sourcemap files are incorrect. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I was able to reproduce this pretty easily using a public repo that I created for a different bug: ``` git clone git@github.com:johncrim/repro-ivy-jest-preset-angular.git git checkout bug/ng11-lib-sourcemap yarn yarn ng build ui-lib ``` This repo is using ng10 dependencies, and the sourcemap is created as expected. Open `./dist/ui-lib/fesm2015/this-ui-lib-expando.js.map` and look at the `"sources"` array: ```json {"version":3,"file":"this-ui-lib-expando.js","sources":["../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando.animations.ts","../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando-panel.component.ts","../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando-panel.module.ts", ... ``` These sourcemaps are correct - it contains correct relative paths to the source files. Then, upgrade the project to Angular 11, and rebuild: ``` yarn ng update @angular/cli @angular/core --force yarn ng build ui-lib ``` Now, looking at the same sourcemap file, you'll see: ```json {"version":3,"file":"this-ui-lib-expando.js","sources":["../../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando.animations.ts","../../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando-panel.component.ts","../../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/expando-panel.module.ts","../../../../libs/ui-lib/expando/src/public-api.ts", ... ``` These sourcemaps are incorrect - they add an extra directory layer, which causes problems when debugging. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 11.0.2
Node: 15.1.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.0.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: i18n: after upgrade to v11 xi18n extracts locales from the imported libraries too
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/localize ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 10.2.2 ### Description Having a custom library which has some locales and ships their translations. Running ng extract-i18n in app which consumes that library, locales from library are also extracted in messages.xlf. As a result, in messages.xlf appears such trans-units ``` interrupted node_modules//__ivy_ngcc__/fesm2015/libname.js 906 ```` In previous version only app's locales are extracted. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 11.0.2
Node: 12.3.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.0.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router
... service-worker
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): apply local libraries sourcemap without `vendor: true`
Issues.Body:
With this change we apply sourcemaps of libraries in a monorepo without the need to enable `vendor: true`. This is more intuitive behavior and  in line with what the users expect.

We also suppress the `Failed to parse source map from` in-actionable warning.

Closes #11305
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): apply local libraries sourcemap without `vendor: true`" (#19446)

Issues.Title: un-referenced files have diagnostics errors after upgrade angular from v5 to 10.2.0
Issues.Body:
After upgration , when I use ng generate commands to generate new components, modules, service etc.. I will get an error from vscode as below:
```

Issues.Title: allow splitting styles.css into multiple chunks and lazy load using defer keyword
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
When having a larger amount of css in the styles.css it causes performance problems when loading the app.
In my case it's because I include font awesome, which in turn includes the blocking loading of the .woff2 file.

I know we can use the √¨nject: false` asset config to handle this ourselves

```
"styles": [
  {
    "input": "src/vendor-fontawesome.scss",
    "inject": false,
    "bundleName": "font-awesome"
  }
],
```

but this means that the file created will not be hashed which means I cannot use `cache-control: immutable`, and it also means the javascript needs to be loaded before I can inject the styles using js.

### Describe the solution you'd like

A solution would be to introduce a `defer: true` value to the config.

```
"styles": [
  'src/styles/main.scss',
  {
    "input": "src/styles/vendor-fontawesome.scss",
    "defer": true
  }
],
```

What this should do is chunk that scss file into it's own css file and add the defer keyword `<link rel="stylesheet" href="..." defer />`

https://web.dev/defer-non-critical-css/

This would mean faster startups, and non essential css could be lazy loaded.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

using `inject: false` and added the `<link href="..." defer />` using javascript

exclude font awesome from my css completely and loading it using a cdn, but then I loose the simplicity of npm and version control.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "allow splitting styles.css into multiple chunks and lazy load using defer keyword" (#19445)

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
@angular/cli

### Description
I was just wondering if you would consider adding mutation testing to the basic generated app. It really helps to learn about creating meaningful unit tets (by far more important than simple coverage)

### Describe the solution you'd like
I know that [stryker](https://stryker-mutator.io/) has support for angular. If it could be added by default to the basic generated app, I think it would help a lot of people improving their skills (as well as mine) for writing unit tests

Issues.Title: bug(Sidenav): Sidenav not displayed on production build
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

This issue occurs only on production build, on dev build the sidenav is displayed correctly. It happens both if using `ng build --prod` and hosting files on a static server or running `ng serve --prod ` directly.

I have created a git repo for reproduction at https://github.com/GCSDC/sidenav-issue

Steps to reproduce (after cloning repo and `npm install`):
1. Run `ng serve --prod`
2. Open app on browser
3. Click the 'Toggle' button to toggle sidenav
 
#### Expected Behavior

Sidenav contents should be displayed correctly, as it happens on a dev build (using `ng build` or `ng serve`):

- CDK/Material: dependencies below
- Browser(s): Chrome Version 86.0.4240.198 (Official Build) (x86_64) / Safari Version 14.0 (15610.1.28.1.9, 15610)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS Catalina 10.15.7

Issues.Title: Angular Material doesn't give clear information about mat-form-field must contain a MatFormFieldControl
Issues.Body:
Angular Material doesn't give clear information about where in the HTML the problem is, instead I got message: "mat-form-field must contain a MatFormFieldControl".

This is uncomfortable because I have component with a 70+ material components, including many inputs, select, datepicker, autocomplete, and I not sure where in  my code I don't have `matInput` for example.

The code I got from my client and in the component, I have 4000+ lines of code and the problem is the message not say where I missing this attribute.

So this is very frustrating. please consider making a change with this.

I suggest something like "input( 30:2) missing matInput" when I wrap inside `mat-form-field` (and so').

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4997825/99879637-d89cf600-2c16-11eb-8013-4b0ae50534cd.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular Material doesn't give clear information about mat-form-field must contain a MatFormFieldControl" (#21109)

Issues.Title: Roboto font moves on page load.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. When page loads for the first time Roboto font that has different font weight e.g 700, 900 moves or scales into place
2. see on https://material.angular.io/ website the hero title "Angular Material" when loaded for first time.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
I expect font not to scale or move.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
The font scales into place or in some cases moves slightly from left to right.

#### Environment

- Angular: 9
- CDK/Material: 9.2.4
- Browser(s): Chrome 
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): 
Macos
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Roboto font moves on page load." (#21118)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-select):  automatic scrolling of options when height of option is set in css
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-16pt1s
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

No scrolling of the options panel when clicking higher numbers in the select list. 


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

When clicking on items (for instance number 50) the panel starts scrolling down to higher numbers because the height of mat-option is set to 30px instead of 48px. 

#### Environment

- Angular: 11.0.2
- CDK/Material: 11.0.0
- Browser(s): Edge, Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-select):  automatic scrolling of options when height of option is set in css" (#21121)

Issues.Title: Datepicker - Cannot select dates
Issues.Body:
Good morning,

Apologies in advance, no reproduction available - probably not possible. This is more of an investigation enquiry as I can't find the cause of the issue.

Recently updated an old project from 8 to 11, and seems the only thing along the way left causing any issue is the date picker.

Date picker seems to be working fine initially - opens in touchUi form and can navigate months:
```
<mat-form-field fxFlexFill>
  <input matInput 
    [value]="value"
    [min]="minDate"
    [max]="maxDate"
    [matDatepicker]="picker"
    [placeholder]="placeholder"
    (dateChange)="onDateChange($event.value)"
    (click)="picker.open()"
    [matDatepickerFilter]="filter"
    [disabled]="disabled">
  <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
  <mat-datepicker touchUi #picker></mat-datepicker>
</mat-form-field>
```

However, I can't click on any of the actual dates (or the years if I open that). Well, I can click on them, but it doesn't do anything (in neither Chrome nor FF).

The `td` elements do have the event listeners attached to them, and a click event is firing and being picked up, but.... nothing happens.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4154268/99936450-199e2300-2d5b-11eb-8f83-740a629c15dd.png)

Hits into here...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4154268/99936485-2ae72f80-2d5b-11eb-9cf3-890cef644874.png)

... But I have no experience with Angular under the hood and following through all of that to make it efficient to attempt such.

Any thoughts on what may be causing this behaviour that I can fix? I doubt it's an issue with material itself in some way (might be, I guess), so what could I possibly have done in this mammoth update process to have killed off date picker clicking, of all things?


My packages:
```
  "dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "11.0.2",
    "@angular/cdk": "11.0.0",
    "@angular/common": "11.0.2",

    "@angular/router": "11.0.2",
    "buffer": "5.6.0",
    "classlist.js": "1.1.20150312",
    "core-js": "3.6.5",
    "hammerjs": "2.0.8",
    "intl": "1.2.5",
    "moment": "2.29.0",
    "rxjs": "6.6.3",
    "tslib": "2.0.3",
    "web-animations-js": "2.3.2",
    "zone.js": "0.10.3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "0.1100.2",
    "@angular/cli": "11.0.2",
    "@angular/compiler-cli": "11.0.2",

Issues.Title: refactor(material/core): resolve circular dependencies
Issues.Body:
Hopefully the last set of code changes for the Sass module system migration.
* Combines `theming/_theming.scss` and `theming/_private.scss`, because they had a circular dependency and since `theming.scss` could be considered a public API, we can't move the utilities out into a shared file.
* Changes the `angular-material-density` mixin to include density mixins individually, instead of going through `angular-material-theme`. The previous approach had transient circular dependencies that will turn into hard errors once we switch to the
Sass module system. The new approach is in line with what we're doing already inside `angular-material-typography`.
* Switches a few MDC function calls to go through `@use` instead of `@import`. For some reason Sass was having a hard time finding the old ones after the files are migrated to the module system.
* Passes a variable as a parameter to `mat-mdc-private-dialog-structure-overrides`, instead of expecting it to be available as a global variable. This seems like an oversight.
* Fixes several places where mixins were being imported transitively, rather than explicitly. This will be an error with the Sass module system.

**Note:** Setting as a P2, because it's a blocker for the Sass module system migration. I'm trying to fix all the errors ahead of time so that the final PR consists only of changes made by the migration script.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(material/core): resolve circular dependencies" (#21110)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/drag-drop): preview not inheriting styles inside shadow dom
Issues.Body:
By default we create a drag preview by cloning the element and inserting the preview at the document root to avoid issues with `overflow: hidden`. The problem is that the clone won't look correctly if the host styles were encapsulated to the shadow DOM.

These changes make it so that we insert the preview at the closest shadow root if the host is inside the shadow DOM, otherwise we fall back to the `body`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/drag-drop): preview not inheriting styles inside shadow dom" (#21107)
